title: Design and Analysis of Multi-Layer and Cuboid Coding Metamaterials for Radar Cross-Section Reduction
summary: This paper presents a design and analysis of multi-layer and cuboid coding metamaterials for reducing Radar Cross-Section (RCS) values in C- and Ku-band applications. The research focuses on developing coding metamaterials with unique properties, which can manipulate electromagnetic waves to achieve different functionalities.
methodology: The authors utilised a high-frequency electromagnetic simulator known as computer simulation technology throughout the simulation process. Analytical simulation analyses were performed using well-known Computer Simulation Technology (CST) software and High-Frequency Structure Simulator (HFSS) software.
research_outcomes: The study presents promising outcomes wherein several one-bit coding designs for multi-layer or coding metamaterials manifested unique results, which almost reached 0 dBm2 RCS reduction values. The coding metamaterials were validated by performing several framework and optimal characteristic analyses in C- and Ku-band applications.
sources_of_inspiration: tensor-coding metasurface at the terahertz frequency

title: Study of wear performance of deep drawing tooling
summary: This paper studies the wear behavior of high carbon high chromium steel, specifically Viking grade steel, under various processing parameters. The research aims to investigate the mechanical and tribological properties of die steel and develop a statistical model to predict wear under dry conditions.
methodology: Experimental investigation using factorial experimental design and analysis of variance (ANOVA) to examine the influences of process parameters on wear behavior
research_outcomes: The study found that Viking grade steel exhibits high toughness and wear resistance. The results show that the wear rate and coefficient of friction are significantly affected by the processing parameters.

title: Understanding and optimization of hard magnetic compounds from first principles
summary: This paper reviews recent developments in computational schemes for rare-earth magnet compounds, focusing on the use of first-principles calculations to understand and design magnetic materials. The authors discuss the limitations of current methods and propose new approaches, including data-driven methods for optimizing chemical composition.
methodology: The paper uses density functional theory (DFT) and other computational schemes to study rare-earth magnet compounds.
research_outcomes: The authors review recent developments in computational schemes for rare-earth magnet compounds, highlighting the importance of first-principles calculations for understanding magnetic properties. They propose new approaches for optimizing chemical composition using data-driven methods.

title: Study on the linkages between microstructure and permeability of porous media using pore network and BP neural network
summary: This paper presents a framework to characterize the pore microstructure of porous media and predict permeability using a combination of pore network modeling (PNM) and back-propagation neural networks (BPNN). The PNM is used to represent the complex geometry of the pore space with morphology parameters, while the BPNN maps these parameters to permeability. The study demonstrates excellent prediction performance of the BPNN and identifies key morphology descriptors that significantly affect permeability.
methodology: The framework consists of four parts: building a dataset of porous media samples, extracting pore networks from images, training a BPNN model to predict permeability, and explaining the trained model. The study uses X-ray micro-computed tomography technology to obtain 3D digital images of porous media.
statistics: Pearson correlation coefficient (PCC) is used to determine linear relationships between morphology parameters and permeability. Feature importance scores are calculated to show which morphology parameters have a significant effect on predicting permeability.
research_outcomes: The study demonstrates that the proposed framework can effectively characterize porous media and predict permeability with high accuracy. The results show that six key morphology descriptors (porosity, coordination number, average pore diameter, average throat diameter, average pore throat ratio, and average throat length) are reserved to characterize pore microstructure.

title: Application of Bayesian Family Classifiers for Cutting Tool Inserts Health Monitoring on CNC Milling
summary: This paper presents the application of supervised Machine Learning classifiers to design empirical classification models for tool condition monitoring in CNC milling. The study uses Bayesian family classifiers, including Bayes Net and Naïve Bayes, to classify tool conditions based on vibration data collected during face milling.
methodology: The study incorporates a statistical approach to extract attributes from vibration data and reduces dimensionality using the J48 decision tree algorithm. The Bayesian classifiers are then used to classify tool conditions.
statistics: Statistical methods, including Principle Component Analysis (PCA) and regression analysis, are used to analyze vibration data.
research_outcomes: The study achieves a classification accuracy of 90% using machine learning algorithms, outperforming traditional condition monitoring methods. The results demonstrate the effectiveness of Bayesian classifiers in tool condition monitoring.

title: An inductively coupled plasma metal organic chemical vapor deposition based on showerhead structure for low temperature growth
summary: This paper proposes a new method for the low-temperature growth of semiconductor thin films using inductively coupled plasma metal organic chemical vapor deposition (ICP-MOCVD) with a showerhead structure. The research focuses on optimizing the showerhead structure to improve uniformity and crystalline quality, but does not involve any machine learning or artificial intelligence methods.
methodology: The authors use computational fluid dynamics (CFD) simulations based on Navier-Stokes equations and laminar flow models to analyze the transport of precursors in the ICP-MOCVD chamber. They also perform preliminary experiments using the optimized showerhead structure.
research_outcomes: The study demonstrates improved uniformity and crystalline quality of GaN films grown at low temperature using the proposed ICP-MOCVD method with a showerhead structure.

title: A New Approach for Measurement of Tensile Strength of Concrete
summary: This paper presents a new approach to measure the tensile strength of concrete using a compression-to-tension load transformer device. The method involves applying compressive loads to the top and bottom of a hole in the specimen, causing it to be subjected to uniaxial tensile stress.
methodology: The methodology involves developing a new loading device called compression-to-tension transformer to apply a tensile stress to the concrete-like specimen. The proposed device is designed and fabricated for use with most commercially available compression loading machines.
research_outcomes: The results show that the direct tensile strength of concrete is clearly lower than the Brazilian test, with a difference of about 33%. The study also presents a criterion for determining the real tensile strength of concrete based on numerical simulation.

title: Damage Monitoring of Single Lap Bonded Composite Using Acoustic Emission Technique
summary: This paper investigates the damage monitoring of single lap bonded composite using acoustic emission technique. The authors experimentally investigate the type of failure involved in single adhesive lap joints of composite and use an acoustic emission technique to monitor the pre and post aspects of damage growth in adhesive composite joint.
methodology: The authors used an acoustic emission technique (AET) to monitor the pre and post aspects of damage growth in adhesive composite joint. The AET was used to scan the pre and post failure mechanism involved during tensile loading.
research_outcomes: The study found that the acoustic emission technique can be used as a failure-monitoring tool for studying damage sensitivity and material degradation.

title: Hydrogen adsorption on doped MoS2 nanostructures
summary: This paper investigates the hydrogen adsorption characteristics in chemically modified MoS2 nanostructures using density functional theory calculations. A machine learning model is used to facilitate the screening of suitable structures, achieving a promising level of prediction accuracy with minimal structural input.
methodology: density functional theory calculations
research_outcomes: The study finds clear benefits of doping the basal plane and provides new insight into doping-enhanced activity. The machine learning model is shown to be effective in screening suitable structures.

title: Critical increase in Na-doping facilitates acceptor band movements that yields ~180 meV shallow hole conduction in ZnO bulk crystals
summary: This paper investigates the effect of Na-doping on the electronic properties of ZnO bulk crystals. The authors report a critical increase in Na-acceptor concentration, which leads to shallow hole conduction and p-type conduction in ZnO crystals.
methodology: The authors used a unique experimental set-up for high Na-doping by thermal diffusion in the bulk ZnO single crystals. They measured the incorporation and concentration of Na-dopants using Secondary-ion mass spectrometry (SIMS).
research_outcomes: The study shows that Na-doping at high temperature leads to a significant increase in Na-acceptor concentration, resulting in shallow hole conduction and p-type conduction in ZnO crystals.

title: Prediction of Endpoint Sulfur Content in KR Desulfurization Based on the Hybrid Algorithm Combining Artificial Neural Network With SAPSO
summary: This paper presents a data-driven model to predict endpoint sulfur content in KR desulfurization process using a hybrid algorithm combining artificial neural network with SAPSO. The proposed model achieves higher accuracy than traditional statistical models and is used to optimize the KR desulfurization process.
methodology: The authors use a hybrid algorithm combining artificial neural network with Particle Swarm Optimization revised by Simulation Anneal algorithm (SAPSO) to predict endpoint sulfur content in KR desulfurization process.
statistics: Correlation Coefficient (R), Root Mean Square Error (RMSE), and Mean Absolute Relative Error (MARE)
research_outcomes: The proposed model achieves higher accuracy than traditional statistical models, with R value of 0.54, RMSE of $2.61	imes 10^{-4}$ % and MAER of 0.47.

title: Design and High-Throughput Screening of High Entropy Alloys
summary: This paper explores the design and high-throughput screening of high entropy alloys, proposing new parameters to predict phase formation. The authors introduce the mixing entropy (ΔS mix ) and Delta (δ) parameter to comprehensively reflect phase formation laws in multi-component alloys.
methodology: The methodology involves designing high-entropy alloys using a balanced parameter, Ω, which is defined as the average melting temperature T m times entropy of mixing Δ S m over enthalpy of mixing Δ H m .
research_outcomes: The authors propose new parameters to predict phase formation in multi-component alloys, including the mixing entropy (ΔS mix ) and Delta (δ) parameter.

title: Editorial on Special Issue “Holography, 3-D Imaging and 3-D Display”
summary: This paper is an editorial that discusses the application of modern holographic techniques in various fields, including 3D inspection, 3D microscopy, metrology and profilometry, augmented reality, and industrial informatics. The paper does not involve any machine learning or artificial intelligence methods.
methodology: The paper discusses the application of modern holographic techniques in various fields, but it does not describe a specific methodology or approach.
research_outcomes: The paper presents an overview of the current state-of-the-art techniques in 3D imaging and 3D display, as well as future development prospects.

title: Predicting Mechanical Properties from Microstructure Images in Fiber-reinforced Polymers using Convolutional Neural Networks
summary: This paper explores the use of convolutional neural networks (CNNs) to predict mechanical properties from microstructure images in fiber-reinforced polymers. The authors modified a pre-existing CNN, StressNet, for non-linear finite element simulations and trained it on data generated from FE simulations. The resulting model can make predictions within seconds, compared to 92.5 hours for the full FE simulation.
methodology: The authors used a fully convolutional neural network with an encoder-decoder structure to predict the stress field from microstructure images. The model was trained on data generated from FE simulations and evaluated using metrics such as accuracy and speed.
research_outcomes: The study shows that CNNs can be used to quickly and accurately predict mechanical properties from microstructure images, making them a promising tool for materials science research. The authors also demonstrate the ability of their model to capture important characteristics, especially on fibers.

title: Evaluation of ANN and ANFIS modeling ability in the prediction of AISI 1050 steel machining performance
summary: This paper evaluates the performance of Artificial Neural Network (ANN) and Adaptive Neuro-Fuzzy Inference System (ANFIS) models in predicting machining responses for AISI 1050 steel turning operation. The study finds that ANN is relatively superior to ANFIS, with a maximum value of 92.1% recorded using the ANN compared to that of the ANFIS of 73%. The results demonstrate the substantial impact of ML/AI on the research, as the models are used to predict machining responses and optimize process parameters.
methodology: The study uses a central composite design (CCD) with three-level experimental matrix to generate data for training, validation, and testing of the ANN model. The network is trained using MATLAB 2016b software, with periodic checking of network error for early stopping.
statistics: Coefficient of correlation (R2), root mean squared error (RMSE)
research_outcomes: The study finds that ANN is relatively superior to ANFIS in predicting machining responses. The results demonstrate the potential of ML/AI in optimizing process parameters and improving machining performance.

title: Frequency-dependent dielectric constant prediction of polymers using machine learning
summary: This paper develops a machine-learning-based model to predict the frequency-dependent dielectric constant of polymers, which is critical for various applications. The model uses a dataset of 1210 experimentally measured values and a hierarchical polymer fingerprinting scheme to accurately and rapidly predict ϵ of new polymer candidates across a wide range of frequencies.
methodology: The methodology involves training an ML model using a dataset of 1210 experimentally measured ϵ values at various frequencies. The model uses a hierarchical polymer fingerprinting scheme and the Gaussian process regression algorithm to capture the frequency-dependent behavior of polymers.
statistics: The paper uses statistical methods such as LASSO for dimensionality reduction and feature elimination.
research_outcomes: The research outcomes include the development of an ML model that can accurately predict ϵ of new polymer candidates across a wide range of frequencies. The model is also used to propose five representative polymers satisfying specific ϵ and T g requirements for capacitor and microelectronic applications.

title: A Study on Casting of Structural Mesh-like Metal Parts
summary: This paper presents a case study on the casting of structural mesh-like metal parts, focusing on cylindrical spacers. The research aims to improve design and manufacturing practices by parametrically defining shapes, examining alternative casting deployment, and ending with prototype manufacture. However, machine learning or artificial intelligence methods are not used in this study.
methodology: The methodology involves numerical simulation using commercially available dedicated software, considering solidification time and lack of defects as primary quality indices accompanied by an investigation of residual stress and deformation fields.
research_outcomes: The research outcomes include the determination of the best combination of casting mode and parameter values for manufacturing cylindrical structural mesh-like metal spacers. The study also investigates the effects of different mold geometries on solidification time and porosity, finding that vacuum casting is preferable to gravity casting.

title: Computational engineering of the oxygen electrode-electrolyte interface in solid oxide fuel cells
summary: This paper focuses on computational modeling of the microstructure evolution at the oxygen electrode–electrolyte interface in solid oxide fuel cells. The authors use thermodynamic, 1D kinetic, and 3D phase-field modeling to study the effects of different ceramic processing techniques for the CGO interlayer and operating parameters on the performance of SOFCs.
methodology: The authors combine thermodynamic, 1D kinetic, and 3D phase-field modeling to computationally reproduce the element redistribution, microstructure evolution, and corresponding ohmic loss of the interface.
research_outcomes: The study shows that computational numerical modeling can be used to optimize the fabrication parameters for SOFCs and minimize the degradation caused by YSZ-CGO interdiffusion and SZO formation.

title: Theoretical and experimental investigations of ultrasonic vibration–assisted boring for titanium alloy
summary: This paper investigates the use of ultrasonic vibration-assisted boring (UB) to improve the quality of machined surfaces in titanium alloy. The authors analyze the kinematics characteristics of UB and compare it with conventional boring, finding that UB can reduce boring force and surface roughness effectively.
methodology: Theoretical and experimental investigations
research_outcomes: UB can reduce boring force and surface roughness effectively

title: Preparation of a low-cost and eco-friendly superabsorbent composite based on wheat bran and laterite for potential application in Chinese herbal medicine growth
summary: This paper focuses on developing a low-cost, eco-friendly superabsorbent composite using wheat bran and laterite for potential application in Chinese herbal medicine growth. The study optimizes the conditions to prepare the WB-g-PAA/LA superabsorbent composite and investigates its properties and applications as a urea fertilizer carrier and in the growth of Chinese herbal medicine.
methodology: The methodology involves free-radical graft co-polymerization of wheat bran, acrylic acid, and laterite in an aqueous solution. The reaction temperature is allowed to increase to 70°C and maintained for 1.5 h to complete polymerization.
research_outcomes: The study finds that the WB-g-PAA/LA superabsorbent composite has high thermal stability, water absorbency, and water-retention capacity. It also regulates the release of urea and influences the growth of Chinese herbal medicine.

title: High Precision, Low Excitation Capacitance Measurement Methods from 10 mK- to Room-Temperature
summary: This paper presents a high precision capacitance measurement method that can measure capacitance from 10 mK to room temperature with excellent accuracy. The method uses a passive bridge at the sample stage and radio frequency excitation to increase the output signal, and develops a high sensitivity radio frequency lock-in technique to analyze the bridge output.
methodology: The paper introduces a new approach for high precision capacitance measurement using a passive bridge at the sample stage and radio frequency excitation. The method uses a voltage-controlled-variable-resistor to in-situ tune the balance of the bridge, and develops a high sensitivity radio frequency lock-in technique to analyze the bridge output.
research_outcomes: The paper presents a high precision capacitance measurement method that can measure capacitance from 10 mK to room temperature with excellent accuracy. The method is capable of resolving 240 ppm variation of a 0.5 pF capacitor within a few second.

title: Automatic segmentation of ceramic materials with relaxed possibilistic c-means clustering for defect detection
summary: This paper proposes a Possibilistic C-Means pixel clustering algorithm with fuzzy stretching to enhance the contrast of ceramic material images for defect detection. The method is shown to be effective in segmenting defects from the background, outperforming standard K-means clustering.
methodology: The proposed method involves preprocessing the image using Gaussian filtering and Max-Min binarization with a Sobel mask, followed by fuzzy stretching to enhance contrast. Then, Possibilistic C-Means pixel clustering is applied to form the target object from the preprocessed image.
research_outcomes: The proposed method was successful in detecting defects in 49 out of 50 images (98% accuracy), outperforming standard K-means clustering.

title: Metal Nanoclusters/Polyvinyl Alcohol Composite Films as the Alternatives for Fabricating Remote-Type White Light-Emitting Diodes
summary: This paper presents a novel approach to fabricating remote-type white light-emitting diodes using metal nanoclusters/polyvinyl alcohol composite films. The research focuses on the synthesis and characterization of these composite materials, which exhibit high emissivity and stability.
methodology: The authors employed a casting method to prepare the MNCs/PVA composite films, followed by various characterization techniques such as TEM, DLS, UV-vis spectroscopy, FTIR, XRD, and AFM.
research_outcomes: The study demonstrates that the MNCs/PVA composite films can be used to fabricate remote-type white LEDs with high color rendering index (CRI) and tunable correlated color temperature (CCT).

title: GaN-based flip-chip LEDs with highly reflective ITO/DBR p-type and via hole-based n-type contacts for enhanced current spreading and light extraction
summary: This paper presents a novel double-layer electrode flip-chip LED (DLE-FCLED) with ITO/DBR p-type contact and via hole-based n-type contacts, which improves light extraction efficiency, current spreading, and heat dissipating. However, machine learning or artificial intelligence methods are not used in this research.
methodology: The methodology involves growing GaN-based LEDs on a c-plane patterned sapphire substrate using metal-organic chemical vapor deposition (MOCVD) technique, followed by fabrication of the DLE-FCLED chip through various processing steps.
research_outcomes: The results show that the DLE-FCLED has improved light extraction efficiency, current spreading, and heat dissipating compared to top-emitting LEDs. The external quantum efficiency (EQE) of DLE-FCLED is enhanced by 15.4% and 132% at 90 mA and 300 mA, respectively.

title: INVESTIGATION ON CRACK ANALYSIS OF H13 FIXED DIE AND STRUCTURAL ANALYSIS OF MOVING DIE WITH TWO DIFFERENT MATERIALS
summary: This paper investigates the physical phenomenon of die casting for two dies (moving die and fixed die) using two different alloy materials. The numerical analysis is carried out to determine the crack formation zone by temperature distribution and structural analysis by stress-strain relationship.
methodology: Numerical analysis using MAGMASOFT software
research_outcomes: The results indicate that the crack zone is obtained at 1.22E-10 °C/mm and 6.856E-14 °C/mm of thermal gradient and structural analysis in terms of maximum stress of 446.94 MPa and 448.52 MPa for aluminum and magnesium alloys, respectively.
